ResponsesInList.Title: How are we supposed to use the AI Subsystem ?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have some questions about the AI subsystem. I use AI in a lot of places in my plugins. I route almost all requests to my own servers and completely bypass the AI subsystem. Partly because this process pre-dates the AI subsystem. And partly because I don't think the AI subsystem does what I need (thats what my questions will be about). But I do want to use it, and ideally I could begin the process of allowing users to route AI requests via the subsystem if they preferred to. As a representative example of a use case - in Poodll Wordcards we need pictures for the WordCards. So I wanted to use the subsystem, and I made a placement plugin so we could generate images. That worked. But then I went back to the old way. Question 1) Do we really need a placement plugin for each place we want to generate a image? (clarification: This is not about using the HTML editor.) I mean, do we need one for Poodll WordCards and one for Poodll MiniLesson and one the Moodle repository etc. Is that really the case? If not, cool. Please tell me what to do instead. If however it is the case. I don't mind coding a few lightweight plugins. I kind of mind having to maintain them on the plugins directory and through each Moodle version update. I do mind having to get my users to install new plugins for what are basically features. Perhaps my needs are some sort of edge case and the html editor is fine for most people. But how about: The file manager - of course we need image generation there. Automated generation content - Poodll has an AI lesson builder it takes a few prompts and goes off builds incredible lessons with loads of images and audio. Most mods will have something like that soon. Bulk image generation - making 10 images in series is slow. Making 10 images in parallel is fast. And that is just images. In fact text generation is a bigger issue. Basically most of my plugins will need a companion AI placement plugin. It seems too much. A hook or callback feature seems more appropriate. Question 2) How about all the other AI things we need to do? A few examples: give students feedback on their submission. give students a score on their submission modify previously generated images transcribe speech. Most of this is programmatic use of AI. Trying to know in advance what kind of AI action is required and make it available as a placement, seems like forever playing catch up. Thats partly because we don't know what we don't know. And partly because AI is advancing at such a rate new functionality is arriving regularly. The list could just get really really long. How do we get new actions into the system? I need all of those things now. Is it possible to have a catch all that allows us to effectively use the engines creds and supply our own implementation of the request and response handling? I mean, I am sure we can do that now, but I do want to play by the rules. Is that against the rules?

ResponsesInList.Title: How are we supposed to use the AI Subsystem ?
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a *really* interesting question Justin, and one that think many developers are struggling with. I feel that that "placements" function is a complex / complicated route to govern where the end-user interaction or initiation of an AI action takes place. This is probably fine in the case of *some* interactions. But I think it overall takes away from the Developer's to make good decisions (or and potentially *bad* decisions) about where and what that initiation looks like. So personally "I" don't like this approach... The other aspect is really the back-end consumption of AI "services" by a Moodle plugin. This in my mind should not need any sort of "placement", it really needs to be a mechanism for the developer to get back some sort of interface that will route their request to a "relevant" / appropriate LLM provider instance. This is of itself a complicated question if we're to allow individual system administrators to have the agency to *decide* which LLM provider they want to use, and this could conflict with some developers who don't want to afford sys-admins that flexiblity (say for instance your AI experience relies on a *very* specific model that *you're* hosting). On this front I prefer the approach the By-cs's local_ai_manager plugin has taken, in offering "purposes" and "providers" so that the systems admin can assert "this LLM is for this purpose", and *every* complying AI plugin that wants to "generate an image" will use it. It doesn't preclude a developer writing an "I need a very specific image generation purpose" and then requiring the admin to wire that purpose up to a very specific LLM instance... (Full disclosure, we've been playing in that very area to look at doing "RAG" and "Text Embedding" purpose for this plugin, so we sort of know that adding newer more specific purposes can be done here). But in both the Moodle system and the By-CS one there is definitely an "arms-length-ness" to calling an LLM, it's by no means "direct" (in Moodle you have go via the placement, and in the local_ai_manager you need to go via a purpose)

ResponsesInList.Title: Local AI
ResponsesInList.Text: At this point, I would also like to mention our free to use and tenant-enabled AI framework local_ai_manager. It offers the possibility to operate a chatbot flexibly with almost any language model, and in particular Ollama. You also have the freedom to set different language models as the basis for the chatbot for different user groups. You can find the ai_manager and all associated plugins at https://moodle.org/plugins/?q=ai_manager

ResponsesInList.Title: Local AI
ResponsesInList.Text: I demonstrated on moodlebande-meeting and mastodon how to run local AI and local Moodle (4.5 - 5.1) in combination with the AI plugin suite from ISB (Bavaria) on a small device such as an Apple MacBook Air with 8 GB RAM and 256 GB SSD or Dell 8 GB RAM and i5-CPU. I successfully tested LM Studio, Ollama, Llama.cpp, and gpt4all working as ai- server . Small LLMs that I tested on the modest hardware in may 2025: https://huggingface.co/microsoft/phi-4-gguf https://huggingface.co/unsloth/Qwen3-1.7B-GGUF/tree/main https://huggingface.co/mradermacher/Ministral-3b-instruct-uncensored-GGUF

ResponsesInList.Title: Local AI
ResponsesInList.Text: For most local AI apps, select the Ollama tool from ISB-suite and add the parameters appropriate for the AI app. For example, Llama.cpp requires the ChatGPT tool instead of the Ollama tool. Local AI apps use the local address and Ollama uses port 11434, LM Studio uses port 1234 Msty uses port 10000 With llama.cpp, you can select the IP and port, e.g.: -- host 192.168.178.20 --port 10000 (this makes llama.cpp accessible via browser using the web interface and via Moodle in the local network)

ResponsesInList.Title: Local AI
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, it is possible to set up and use a local language model like Ollama instead of using OpenAI‚Äôs cloud models. Just simply follow these steps to set up Ollama: 1. Install Ollama 2. Run a model 3. List available models. You can connect Ollama with other tools or apps like LMStudio, LangChain, and VSCode Extension. Hope this will help you.

ResponsesInList.Text: This also raises the question as what you mean by "all the questions must be generated by AI". The generation that Phillipp mentions will use AI and the guidance you provide into the generator to create Moodle questions, but if you're talking about something which inherently "knows" about your cours content, and uses that to "ground" the generation in that context / content, then you're starting to get in to the realms of needing some sort of Retrieval Augmented Generation process that can expose the relevant content in your Moodle course. This is basically just accelerating what the generator above does, and changes it so that you're not having to do it "by hand". This is something however that I'm working with Phillipp with to make Moodle course content accessible via a RAG process, so that an AI tool (like the generator) could get that context directly from Moodle instead of from "you" (manually). But it's a work in progress...

ResponsesInList.Title: Gemini and DeepSeek
ResponsesInList.Text: Shesah, the best way to get good answers to questions in general is to provide as much information as possible, about what you want, what you have and what you expect. Your posts so far have been information light. For example what do you mean by "Latest Moodle". Also what sources have you read, where are you expecting to get these services from. ResponsesInList.Title: Gemini and DeepSeek
ResponsesInList.Text: To expland further there is a difference between an inference provider and a model. You can access the deepseek model(s) from deepseek.com but you can also acces them from Groqcloud (which is very fastr) They key to all of it is the OpenAI compatibility layer, so I tweaked the OpenAI provider to call out to Groqcloud using OpenAI compatible calls. I suspect that is also possible with Gemini (a very nice model), but Gemini is only available directly from Google. My interpretation is that Moodle HQ are focussed on offering a relatively narrow range of options e.g. OpenAI/Azure (the same thing for most purposes) and with Moodle 5 Ollama, support. Other people can create plugins to support other services. For example i created a basic one one for Groq https://github.com/marcusgreen/moodle-aiprovider_groq Which should allow you to talk to Deepseek 70b, various versions of LLama from meta or Gemma (a lightweight version of gemini) https://blog.google/technology/developers/gemma-open-models/ But it would be good to step back and work out what you want and expect from these things. One way is to go to the "playgrounds" they provide and experiment with some prompts to work out what benefit you might get. You can see the things that I have been working on getting AI to do with Moodle here

ResponsesInList.Title: Gemini and DeepSeek
ResponsesInList.Text: Shesha, have you tried the OpenAI Provider service with Moodle? The key to working with a different service is to confirm that they offer an OpenAI compatible end point, find that end point, e.g. for Groq (one of them) is https://api.groq.com/openai/v1/chat/completions Then¬† get¬† key and an organisationid. Find out what models are available and see if it works with either the OpenAI provider or the Ollama provider For example you can see the Groq models here https://console.groq.com/docs/models This is a very rapidly changing environment and you will need to experiment to find out about new things that are being developed. ResponsesInList.Title: Gemini and DeepSeek
ResponsesInList.Text: "Moodle should be flexible to welcome all AI API providers." it does, I wrote one, see the link I provided. You could use that to access a version of DeepSeek at no financial cost, have you tried that? If you would like access to other systems you could either write the code for it yourself or commission someone else to write one. The development time is measured in days rather than weeks. "For this, the current AI m. For this, the current AI module should be updated so that it allows any type of AI API provider. Module should be updated so that it allows any type of AI API provider. " Moodle HQ cannot predict every possible variation on AI/LLM provider. There is a de-facto industry standard of the OpenAI API which is supported by many systems and by Moodle starting with 4.5. What do you want to use AI with Moodle for, why are you interested in these other models? Remember Moodle HQ makes no financial charge for the software and there are over 440 million user accounts globally so every feature requires extensive testing and maintenance which does have a financial cost. If you have any follow up questions, expand on what you have done so far with Moodle AI and what you are hoping to do with it in the future.

ResponsesInList.Title: Gemini and DeepSeek
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, below are simple ways to use Gemini and DeepSeek AI in Moodle. Ways to use Gemini AI in Moodle: 1. Log in to Moodle. 2. Access Gemini AI 3. Start a Gemini AI session 4. Type your question or tasks 5. Select Output type 6. Generate output 7. Use or save output. Ways to use DeepSeek AI in Moodle: 1. Log in to Moodle 2. Access DeepSeek AI 3. Choose the search type 4. Enter your query 5. Review AI Result 6. Select and use results. Gemini and DeepSeek AI both work with clear and specific prompts. I hope this will help. Mamta Bankoti

ResponsesInList.Title: Cursive authorship and writing plugin
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, we've successfully navigated the community plugin review process, and our plugin for Moodle is now available (). Special thanks to the Brainstation23 development team. This plugin is for TinyMCE , and has some free features (citation builder, playback). When connected to the Cursive API/ML server (paid service), it leverages ML to verify authorship for writing within Moodle, ensuring the same author session to session. We're not identifying "who," but rather, we're verifying that the author is consistent over time and that the effort of writing was captured (no matter how much or little; if you want to see "v" from a copy-paste... well, we see that too). We've built it to support Forums Online assignments Essays in Quizzes I'm a big believer in the power of writing as an essential skill, the importance of writing skills development, and transparency. While my initial goal was to thwart contract cheating/essay mill usage and promote integrity/verify student effort, we are working hard to leverage the same writing process data to also expose new and helpful data for both teachers and students: time/duration (available) editing amounts (available) pasted text (available) writing playback (available) quality metrics (coming very soon) This isn't an AI Classifier, but we do leverage and intend to provide more AI/machine learning to help writers become better writers, even if/when responsible AI use is allowed or required . If you have any questions, please let me know!

" Although the AI is very capable out-of-the-box, if it doesn't know the answer to a question, it is more likely to confidently give incorrect information than to refuse to answer. The plugin provides a text area at both the block instance level as well as the plugin level where teachers or administrators can include a list of questions and answers that the AI will ingest before generating a completion; as a result, the AI is more likely to provide accurate information when a submitted query is similar to the questions it has been given direct answers to. ResponsesInList.Title: AI chat block
ResponsesInList.Text: We also built out a rudimentary Moodle RAG system on top of the SOLR backend (which is also available for Global Search): https://github.com/mhughes2k/moodle-search_solrrag The issue we found isn't just respecting what sources the user has access to, there is a separate question of which sources are permissmible to be used in an AI action. For instance a PDF of a Journal article could be added to a Moodle site, but there is no way to say that it can't be parsed to create an embedding or that it's retrieved content can't then be passed on for summarisation. At the moment there is no mechanism to describe the permitted uses of content.

ResponsesInList.Title: AI chat block
ResponsesInList.Text: I was quite excited when I first used it and there is nothing inherently wrong with it as a Chat block. I liked the way you could use your own "source of truth".. However I am not convinced that ChatBlocks offer the most effective and safe use of AI. The people at Mebis (Bavaria) have a whole suite of plugins (including a chat block) that focus on privacyt/data protection/token counting/limiting who has access to the AI. https://github.com/orgs/bycs-lp/repositories They also use my own AI Text question type which uses an AI to give feedback to quiz questions.¬† Their Question generation plugin is very impressive. You can see my presentation about my Quiz question type in this video. (let me know if that works or search on Moodle Academy ai if that link doesn't work)... It may seem like AI in education is everywhere but in reality it is early days and things are changing very, very quickly.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AI providers & AI placements... no joy!
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, AL, for your response. I use Paid OpenAI. I spent 2 hours with ChatGPT4o. We solved the problem! Here is how: Problem: Moodle AI plugin failed with "cURL error 60" due to missing SSL root certificates on Windows (I run Moodle on Windows Server 2025). Fix: 1. Download cacert.pem from https://curl.se/ca/cacert.pem 2. Save it to: C:\moodle\certs\cacert.pem 3. Edit php.ini to add: curl.cainfo = "C:\moodle\certs\cacert.pem" 4. (Optional) Also add: openssl.cafile = "C:\moodle\certs\cacert.pem" 5. Restart Apache / IIS /PHP

ResponsesInList.Title: feedback on AI plugin
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, I've been going through the AI section of the forum for the first time, and I see a real interest in it (but also how complex it is to set up). That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm doing my bit. We released the Corolair AI Tutor plugin in mid-January, and it‚Äôs been downloaded nearly 150 times. If you're a Moodle admin , I‚Äôd love feedback on the implementation and how it fits into your workflow. We want to simplify installation and reduce installs that never get tested. If you're a teacher , how do you use Moodle for your courses? How has AI changed your work and your students' learning? We're focused on making AI in Moodle a real Human + AI collaboration - not just another tool, but something that truly supports teachers and learners without taking over. AI should help structure, engage, and adapt learning, but always with a human in control. Thank you in advance for your help. Romain

ResponsesInList.Title: feedback on AI plugin
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Romain! üòä It's amazing to see initiatives like the Corolair AI Tutor being developed for Moodle! AI has enormous potential to transform education, but as you mentioned, the challenge is making it a true ally for teachers and students without it feeling like a complex or bureaucratic tool. I understand this well, as I also try to create tools to make teachers' lives easier. I tested the plugin and noticed that installation can still be a sensitive point for many administrators. Moodle is vast, and each environment has its peculiarities, so a guided setup assistant would be a fantastic feature! Something that helps detect permissions, API keys, and necessary configurations automatically, reducing that initial frustration of "what do I do now?". For teachers, I see that adapting activities based on student progress would be one of the most powerful uses of AI. If Corolair can, for example, suggest supplementary materials or dynamically adapt quizzes based on student performance, it would be revolutionary! Imagine a quiz that changes questions according to the student's mistakes and successes, creating a unique learning path. That would be a true intelligent tutor! The idea of keeping the teacher in control is essential! AI needs to be a support tool, not a replacement. A dashboard where teachers can view AI suggestions, approve them, or adjust them before they are applied would make usage much safer and more reliable. I'm really curious to see how Corolair evolves, and I'm here to help with whatever you need! üöÄ If you need more testing, feedback, or even help in the community, count on me! Eduardo Kraus Innovation and new products

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle5: Ollama-API- Provider not working
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andr√©, I'd suggest you to try without auth first. Just to confirm if the problem is the auth or the use of the API. There are a couple of things that have called my attention: The API endpoint: Unless your configuration is special, it should be the base Ollama URL , AKA, without the `/api` (that's automatically added by Moodle). Note that, IMO , it should be the other way, but I've just tried here and what seems to work is to add the base Ollama URL, not the API URL. ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle5: Ollama-API- Provider not working
ResponsesInList.Text: My colleague found the error. It's just a string in `ollama/provider.php` that's incorrect. +++ ai/provider/ollama/classes/provider.php 2025-04-28 14:40:59 +0000 @@ -55,7 +55,7 @@ #[\Override] public function add_authentication_headers(RequestInterface $request): RequestInterface { - ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†if (empty($this->config['basicauthenabled'])) { // original code + ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†if (empty($this->config['enablebasicauth'])) { // corrected code return $request; } else { // Add the Authorization header for basic auth. The correction made is that `basicauthenabled` was changed to `enablebasicauth` Now it works for me. I will try to open an issue in tracker.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ollama with olmo2 - no summarize for resource page
ResponsesInList.Text: Yesterday, I was having fun with two of my Raspberry Pi5's, comparing results of the one with the new 26 TOPS AI HAT to another with a SSD HAT. I was puzzled that both of them had almost the exact same verbose results, but I was interrupted further investigations by one of those necessary life events that butted in...had to go grocery shopping! LOL When I got back, it suddenly dawned on me why they were giving me very similar results. The Pi 5's have a new PCI Express Interface ribbon connector on the rear edge of the board. The AI HAT uses that connection for the communicating with the AI HAT, meaning the OS and memory storage all has to go on a Micro SDC memory chip. The other PI with a 1TB SSD, is running the OS and memory storage on the SSD and does not even have a Micro SDC memory chip plugged in. When I got that particular Pi 5, I had to do an initial setup using a Micro SDC memory chip and was amazed how much faster it appeared when I finished moving the OS over to the SSD. I currently have Ollama set up on it using the llama3.2:3b model which granted, is not as fast with it's answers, as those you can get elsewhere, but, as I have mentioned before, no matter how much I ask it, it will not suddenly want to start charging me for access to it. If anyone want to try it out, send me a private message with a desired user name and password so I can set it up. If anyone is interested, note that I have created an AI provider plugin like the two now included in Moodle, and hope to get the settings to work with one of my Pi's, soon. Almost forgot to mention, if you want to try AI on your OWN Raspberry Pi, try to get a 16GB version. Makes a huge difference in which models you can run/use.

The answers are different too. The Moodle generated JSON received the following resopnse: `{` `"id": "chatcmpl-700",` `"object": "chat.completion",` `"created": 1738909100,` `"model": "llama3.1:8b",` `"system_fingerprint": "fp_ollama",` `"choices": [` `{` `"index": 0,` `"message": {` `"role": "assistant",` `"content": ""` `},` `"finish_reason": "stop"` `}` `],` `"usage": {` `"prompt_tokens": 16,` `"completion_tokens": 1,` `"total_tokens": 17` `}` `}` Empty "content" where the working requests get a whole load of "response" data like the ones below: `{"model":"llama3.1:8b","created_at":"2025-02-07T06:18:03.267790051Z","response":" combination","done":false}` `{"model":"llama3.1:8b","created_at":"2025-02-07T06:18:03.286865819Z","response":" of","done":false}` `{"model":"llama3.1:8b","created_at":"2025-02-07T06:18:03.305958078Z","response":" machine","done":false}` `{"model":"llama3.1:8b","created_at":"2025-02-07T06:18:03.325020031Z","response":" learning","done":false}` Running the data through curl alone yielded no real improvement in the situation other than I now have a hypothesis that maybe the API endpoint specified is not able to handle data in the structures it was provided by Moodle. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ollama and Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Adam, I think that you may be mixing APIs here. Ollama supports 2 REST APIS: The Ollama API ( link to docs ) is the native Ollama one, more powerful, but proprietary (only Ollama understands it). It includes endpoint like `/api/generate` , `/api/embed` , ... and many others. The OpenAI API ( link to docs ) is the one providing compatibility with any client able to use that "de-facto" standard. It doesn't have all the features that the Ollama one has, but it's the one to use when wanting to connect to it when using an OpenAI-compatible client. It includes endpoints like `/v1/chat/completions` , `/v1/embeddings` , ... and a few others. In the case of Moodle 4.5, it's only able to use the 2nd one, because the available provider is the OpenAI one, that is, Moodle is an OpenAI-compatible client. And that's the one that you should be using. Incoming Moodle 5.x (I don't know the exact details) will come also with a "native" Ollama provider, that will use the other API, It's actually being worked on @ MDL-83006 . So, back to the issue, the type of requests that Moodle generates right now are the OpenAI ones, and they are the ones to allow in your reverse proxy or whatever. Apart from that, I cannot imagine any problem, as far as the `curlsecurityblockedhosts` and `curlsecurityallowedport` Moodle settings are ok and the `OLLAMA_HOST` env variable has been set in order to bind to non-loopback/remote interfaces. That's what the Ollama specific article in the docs tries to explain. Feel free to improve it, it's a wiki! I've tried here, right now, with `https://some.host.where.ollama.runs:11434/v1/chat/completions` configured as the end point for summaries in Moodle 4.5, and it's working perfectly. Ciao

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ollama and Moodle
Re: Ollama and Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: UPDATE SOLVED! OK, so the solution here is infuriatingly simple: Moodle core_ai needs to have an API Key set before it even tries to do anything. Ollama doesn't require an API Key, in fact. even having an API Key set, it goes completely ignored, but it must be set. OK, I'm off to add this to the Ollama documentation page. Already have seen another post in these forums where someone else was suffering from the same malady as I was. For anyone who is curious about how I found the answer, I was looking over the Ollama documentation about OpenAI compatibility (it's installed in Ollama by default BTW, no additional config required) and saw the highlighted snippet in the OpenAI Python library... It's infuriating just how simple the solution is. Definitely going straight to the docs to add this information.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle AI Provider Benchmarking
ResponsesInList.Text: Has any benchmark testing been done by Moodle or anyone else to determine: a) the best model to use and the trade offs between price and performance (on both OpenAI and Azure AI you get a list of different models that you can choose from that have different pricing) and what additional safety services are required with the AI service for AI placements to be made available to students? b) the impact of enabling Moodle AI placements on Moodle infrastructure - server & DB performance, UX latency, additional logging and monitoring required c) the risk exposure against AI specific security exploits e.g. against MITRE ATLAS d) what's the best way to purchase these AI services to provide an acceptable baseload performance and the ability to scale them up for peak load? e) a method for projecting the additional budget required to add AI to Moodle e.g. for every 1,000 students add X% to your Moodle hosting and X% to cover the AI costs I haven't found anything published yet that addresses any one of these issues which are all important considerations to scaling out Moodle AI features in production. Keen to hear people thoughts and lessons/war stories

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle AI Provider Benchmarking
ResponsesInList.Text: There is no single bench mark to address these questions. a) Best Model:It depends. For example if you want to teach languages it might be best to use a model optimised for that. If you want to do Maths you might decide not to use an LLM (inherently unreliable) b) Performance: Probably minimal, the interesting stuff happens outside Moodle c) Risk: There is little that Moodle can do to mitigate risky content but generally it should not compromise security as "traditionally" concerning with a system like Moodle. So for example AI use is probably not going to facilitate getting admin access. I have been working on using regular expressions to identify attempted prompt injection attacks but that is more about general warnings than any actual fixes. d) LLM Performance: That is a good question. One approach is to go for big suppliers and have a large amount of contingeny money. I don't mean to be flippant but if AI is really important to you that is a solution. However as someone who is very engaged with Moodle and AI I advise against making AI reliability (in any interpretation) central to your plans at the moment. e) Costs: I have been vigoriously experimenting with AI with Moodle for over 12 months and my total spend has been less than ¬£US50 (all with OpenAI). During that time Open AI has halved its rate per million tokens (someone confirm that for me). I believe the cost of inference will "fall off a cliff", due to both hardware and software developments. Inference will always have a financial cost, but possibly in the same way that broadband and internet access will always have a cost.

ResponsesInList.Title: AI Rubric Generation and Grading of Rubric Based Assignments
ResponsesInList.Text:
Good day everyone,

I just finished a capstone project for my MA in Software Engineering and my team is interested in seeing if any organizations using Moodle might be interested in trying the product we developed. It has two key components:

1. AI generation of assessments that can be automatically imported as Moodle Quizzes
2. AI generation of Rubrics that can be imported as Rubric based assignments into Moodle and then also use AI to grade submissions and import the complete graded rubric and comments back into Moodle.

The application framework is Flutter/Dart and we have it available for review in Github. No local data storage is used as the system leverages the user's Moodle account and the Moodle data/auth/roles to define what can be done in the app. No personally identifiable information is sent to the AI; only the required prompt and assignment submission/rubric.

Teachers have the ability to override, edit, or otherwise adjust all AI generated content or grading.

The app can be run as a web app or natively as a Windows, MacOS, Linux, Android, or iOS application.

Our goal is to collect teacher data about using AI as a teacher helper tool and if our application has any impact on teachers' attitudes about AI use.

Please contact me if you have any questions or would like to talk about the details.

Thank you,
Scott McGlynn

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to limit the AI summarize function to certain activities?
ResponsesInList.Text: For the time being, no, unfortunately. You can prevent students from seeing the summarise button in the whole course by overriding the capability aiplacement/courseassist:summarise_text for that particular course but not for individual activities within the course. There is a tracker issue to improve this and you might like to watch or vote for it: / MDL-83156 AI: Improve user access controls.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to limit the AI summarize function to certain activities?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the update, Mary.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to limit the AI summarize function to certain activities?
ResponsesInList.Text: I added a note to the AI placements documentation about restricting placements, ie how to prevent students from generating summarised content, etc.

ResponsesInList.Title: AI providers priority
ResponsesInList.Text: If an institution has both Azure and OpenAI accounts enabled in its Moodle as AI providers and the ones are set up so that the Action "Generate text" is enabled for each provider, what provider will be actually used for text generation?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AI providers priority
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Alex! üòä I ran some tests, and the default behavior is that Moodle prioritizes OpenAI as the primary provider for this action. In other words, when you click to generate text, OpenAI is the one that "steps in." Eduardo Kraus Teacher and programmer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AI providers priority
ResponsesInList.Text: I am curious as to if this is "an accident" or by design. I recently investigated the Azure service and apart from appearing to be more complex to configure (I never got it to work entirely) it also appears to offer the same models as OpenAI. This makes me wonder what the benefit of using Asure is.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AI providers priority
ResponsesInList.Text: None....

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AI providers priority
ResponsesInList.Text: It took a long to get the answer Thank you, Eduardo! I wonder why this issue is not covered in the documentation..

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AI providers priority
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Alex! How are you? I'm glad you found the answer, I'm really happy I could help! üéâ Regarding your question, I totally understand the frustration of not finding a specific solution in the documentation. That happens sometimes because documentation doesn't always cover all possible situations, especially when it comes to integrations with new technologies or adjustments that come up day-to-day. Personally, I don‚Äôt always look at the documentation directly, because often practice and experimentation teach us much faster. And many times, checking the code on https://github.com/moodle/moodle/ is quicker üòâ Eduardo Kraus Professor and Programmer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AI providers priority
ResponsesInList.Text: Azure might be preferred if https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/copilot/microsoft-365/enterprise-data-protection is turned on ? These would be privacy / safety reasons.

ResponsesInList.Title: AI for the n00b
ResponsesInList.Text: Suddenly it started raining AI everywhere. The AI dept. of moodle.org was somewhere else, so offered no shelter. Since I avoid G-places I had nowhere to go. Today a web search brought me this - AI enhanced? Maybe. Still, I don't want to withhold it from you. How to Protect Yourself from AI by Understanding THIS https://odysee.com/@RobBraxmanTech:6/goodai:8 The title is misleading. It is the first of a series of talks, I think. This one just introduces the terms. Therefore be warned, only for the absolute n00b. ;)
